credentialsPage.title: Credentials
credentialsPage.empty.title: You don't have any credentials.
credentialsPage.empty.subtitle: Click the <bold>Add credentials</bold> button to create your resource.
credentials.tableHeader.name: Name
credentialsForm.title.tooltip: A credential stores the access credentials and configuration information for creating clusters.
credentialsForm.cancelButton.label: Cancel
credentialsForm.updated.title: Credentials updated
credentialsForm.created.title: Credentials created
credentialsForm.credentialsType.title: Credentials type
credentialsForm.credentialsType.wizardDe: What are the different credentials types?
credentialsForm.credentialsType.label: Credentials type
credentialsForm.basicInformation.title: Basic information
credentialsForm.credentialsName.label: Credentials name
credentialsForm.credentialsName.placehol: Enter the name for the credentials
credentialsForm.namespaceName.label: Namespace
credentialsForm.namespaceName.labelHelp: The existing namespace where the credentials secret will be stored.
credentialsForm.namespaceName.placeholde: Select a namespace where to store the credentials
credentialsForm.providerName.label: Provider
credentialsForm.providerName.labelHelp: The infrastructure provider for the selected Kubernetes distribution.
credentialsForm.providerName.placeholder: Select a provider for the credentials
credentialsForm.awsCredentials.title: Amazon Web Services
credentialsForm.awsCredentials.wizardTit: Enter the Amazon Web Services credentials
credentialsForm.awsCredentials.wizardDes: How do I get Amazon Web Service credentials?
credentialsForm.aws_access_key_id.label: Access key ID
credentialsForm.aws_access_key_id.labelH: You use access keys to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. The access key is equivalent to a username in a username/password combination.
credentialsForm.aws_access_key_id.placeh: Enter your AWS access key ID
credentialsForm.aws_secret_access_key.la: You use access keys to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. The secret access key is equivalent to a password in a username/password combination.
credentialsForm.aws_secret_access_key.pl: Enter your AWS secret access key
credentialsForm.azureCredentials.title: Microsoft Azure
credentialsForm.azureCredentials.wizardD: How do I get Microsoft Azure credentials?
credentialsForm.baseDomainResourceGroupN: Azure Resources Groups are logical collections of virtual machines, storage accounts, virtual networks, web apps, databases, and/or database servers. Typically, users group related resources for an application, divided into groups for production and non-production.
Enter your base domain resource group name
credentialsForm.clientId.label: Client ID
credentialsForm.clientId.labelHelp: Your client ID. This value is generated as the 'appId' property when you create a service principal with the command: 'az ad sp create-for-rbac --role Contributor --name <service_principal>'.
credentialsForm.clientSecret.label: Client secret
credentialsForm.clientSecret.labelHelp: Your client password. This value is generated as the 'password' property when you create a service principal with the command: 'az ad sp create-for-rbac --role Contributor --name <service_principal>'.
credentialsForm.subscriptionId.label: Subscription ID
credentialsForm.subscriptionId.labelHelp: Your subscription ID. This is the value of the 'id' property in the output of the command: 'az account show'
credentialsForm.tenantId.label: Tenant ID
credentialsForm.tenantId.labelHelp: Your tenant ID. This is the value of the 'tenantId' property in the output of the command: 'az account show'
credentialsForm.gcpCredentials.title: Google Cloud Platform
credentialsForm.gcpCredentials.wizardTit: Enter the Google Cloud Platform credentials
credentialsForm.gcpCredentials.wizardDes: How do I get Google Cloud Platform credentials?
credentialsForm.projectID.label: Project ID
credentialsForm.projectID.labelHelp: A project organizes all of your Google Cloud resources. A project consists of a set of users; a set of APIs; and billing, authentication, and monitoring settings for those APIs. So, for example, all of your Cloud Storage buckets and objects, along with user permissions for accessing them, reside in a project.
credentialsForm.projectID.placeholder: Enter your Google Cloud Platform project ID
credentialsForm.osServiceAccount.json.la: Creating a service account is similar to adding a member to your project, but the service account belongs to your applications rather than an individual end user.
credentialsForm.osServiceAccount.json.pl: Enter your Google Cloud Platform service account JSON key
credentialsForm.vCenter.title: VMWare
credentialsForm.vCenter.wizardDescriptio: How do I get VMWare credentials?
credentialsForm.vCenter.label: vCenter server
credentialsForm.vCenter.labelHelp: The fully-qualified host name or IP address of the vCenter server. The value must be defined in the vCenter server root CA certificate.
credentialsForm.username.label: vCenter username
credentialsForm.username.labelHelp: The name of the user that is required to access the vCenter server. This user must have at least the roles and privileges that are required for static or dynamic persistent volume provisioning in vSphere.
credentialsForm.password.label: vCenter password
credentialsForm.password.labelHelp: The password associated with the vCenter username.
credentialsForm.cacertificate.label: vCenter root CA certificate
credentialsForm.cacertificate.labelHelp: A vCenter server root CA certificate that, when added, reduces the number of web browser certificate warnings.
credentialsForm.cacertificate.placeholde: Enter your vCenter root CA certificate
credentialsForm.cluster.label: vSphere cluster name
credentialsForm.cluster.labelHelp: The name of the vSphere cluster to use.
credentialsForm.datacenter.label: vSphere datacenter
credentialsForm.datacenter.labelHelp: The name of the vSphere datacenter to use.
credentialsForm.defaultDatastore.label: vSphere default defaultDatastore
credentialsForm.defaultDatastore.labelHe: The name of the default vSphere defaultDatastore to use.
credentialsForm.bareMetalCredentials.wiz: How do I get bare metal credentials?
credentialsForm.libvirtURI.label: libvirt URI
credentialsForm.libvirtURI.labelHelp: The URI of the libvirt which is an open-source API, daemon and management tool for managing platform virtualization. It can be used to manage KVM, Xen, VMware ESXi, QEMU and other virtualization technologies. These APIs are widely used in the orchestration layer of hypervisors in the development of a cloud-based solution.
credentialsForm.sshKnownHosts.label: List of SSH known hosts
credentialsForm.sshKnownHosts.labelHelp: SSH clients store host keys for hosts to which they have previously connected. These stored host keys are called known host keys, and the collection is often called known hosts.
credentialsForm.sshKnownHosts.placeholde: Enter your list of SSH known hosts
credentialsForm.bareMetalDisconnected.wi: Enter the configuration for disconnected installation
How do I configuration for disconnected installation?
credentialsForm.imageMirror.label: Image registry mirror
credentialsForm.imageMirror.labelHelp: Optional: Disconnected registry path, defined as hostname, port and repository path. It must contain all the installation images, and is used in disconnected installations. Example: repository.com:5000/openshift/ocp-release.
credentialsForm.bootstrapOSImage.label: Bootstrap OS image
credentialsForm.bootstrapOSImage.labelHe: This value contains the URL to the image to use for the bootstrap machine. The value must also contain the SHA-256 hash of the image.
credentialsForm.bootstrapOSImage.placeho: Enter your bootstrap OS image.  The value must also contain the SHA-256 hash of the image.
credentialsForm.clusterOSImage.label: Cluster OS image
credentialsForm.clusterOSImage.labelHelp: This value contains the URL to the image to use for Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform cluster machines.  The value must also contain the SHA-256 hash of the image.
credentialsForm.clusterOSImage.placehold: Enter your cluster OS image.  The value must also contain the SHA-256 hash of the image.
credentialsForm.additionalTrustBundle.la: This value provides the contents of the certificate file that is required to access the mirror registry.
credentialsForm.baseDomain.label: Base DNS domain
credentialsForm.baseDomain.labelHelp: Optional: The base domain of your provider, which is used to create routes to your OpenShift Container Platform cluster components. It is configured in your cloud provider's DNS as a Start Of Authority (SOA) record.
credentialsForm.pullSecret.title: Pull secret and SSH
credentialsForm.pullSecret.wizardTitle: Enter the pull secret and SSH keys
credentialsForm.pullSecret.wizardDescrip: How do I get the Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform pull secret?
credentialsForm.pullSecret.label: Pull secret
credentialsForm.pullSecret.labelHelp: The pull secret that you obtained from the pull secret page on the Red Hat OpenShift Cluster Manager site. Use this pull secret to authenticate with the services that are provided by the included authorities, including Quay.io, which serves the container images for OpenShift Container Platform components.
credentialsForm.pullSecret.placeholder: Enter Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform pull secret
credentialsForm.sshPrivateKey.label: SSH private key
credentialsForm.sshPrivateKey.labelHelp: The private SSH key to use to access your cluster machines.
credentialsForm.sshPublicKey.label: SSH public key
credentialsForm.sshPublicKey.labelHelp: The public SSH key to use to access your cluster machines.
credentialsForm.openshiftCredentials.wiz: Enter the OpenShift Cluster Manager API token
How do I get the OpenShift Cluster Manager API Token?
credentialsForm.ocmapitoken.label: OpenShift Cluster Manager API token
credentialsForm.ocmapitoken.labelHelp: The OpenShift Cluster Manager API Token can be retrieved from - https://cloud.redhat.com/openshift/token
credentialsForm.ocmapitoken.placeholder: Enter the OpenShift Cluster Manager API token
credentialsForm.openStackCredentials.wiz: How do I get OpenStack credentials?
credentialsForm.clouds.yaml.label: OpenStack clouds.yaml
credentialsForm.clouds.yaml.labelHelp: The OpenStack clouds.yaml file, including the password, to connect to the OpenStack server.
credentialsForm.clouds.yaml.placeholder: Enter the contents of the OpenStack clouds.yaml
credentialsForm.cloud.label: Cloud name
credentialsForm.cloud.labelHelp: The name of the cloud section of the clouds.yaml to use for establishing communication to the OpenStack server.
credentialsForm.cloud.placeholder: Enter the OpenStack cloud name to reference in the clouds.yaml
credentialsForm.ansibleCredentials.label: Ansible Automation Platform credential
credentialsForm.ansibleCredentials.title: Ansible Automation Platform
credentialsForm.ansibleCredentials.wizar: Enter the Ansible Automation Platform credentials
How do I get Ansible Automation Platform credentials?
credentialsForm.ansibleHost.label: Ansible Tower host
credentialsForm.ansibleHost.placeholder: Enter the Ansible Tower host URL
credentialsForm.ansibleToken.label: Ansible Tower token
validate.kubernetesDnsName.length: This value can contain at most 63 characters
validate.kubernetesDnsName.char: This value can only contain lowercase alphanumeric characters or '-'
validate.kubernetesDnsName.startchar: This value must start with an alphanumeric character
validate.kubernetesDnsName.endchar: This value must end with an alphanumeric character
validate.publicSshKey: Must be a valid public key
validate.privateSshKey: Must be a valid private key
validate.mustEndWithNewline: Must end with a new line
validate.projectID.format: Must consist of 6 to 30 lowercase alphanumeric characters or '-', and must start with a letter and not end with '-'
validate.imageMirror.format: Value must have the format HOSTNAME:PORT/PATH
validate.imageMirror.repositorypath: Value for the repository path must consist of alphanumeric characters, '-', '.' or '_', and must start and end with an alphanumeric character
validate.baseDnsName.char: Must consist of lower case alphanumeric characters, '-' or '.', and must start and end with an alphanumeric character
validate.baseDnsName.start: The base DNS domain must not begin with a period.
validate.baseDomain.baseDNSPeriod: The base DNS domain must not begin with a period.
validate.baseDomain.name: Must consist of lower case alphanumeric characters, '-' or '.', and must start and end with an alphanumeric character
validate.yaml.not.valid: The yaml file is not valid.
validate.yaml.no.clouds: The yaml file does not contain a clouds: element.
validate.yaml.cloud.not.found: The cloud name was not found in clouds.yaml.
bulk.message.delete: You cannot create new clusters from deleted credentials. Clusters that you previously created will not be affected.
